intro: Paepalanthus verae, commonly known as the Andean sunflower, is a flowering plant native to the Andean regions of South America. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble sunflowers. The plant typically grows in high-altitude environments, thriving in cool and temperate climates. It produces bright yellow flowers that bloom in the spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its unique appearance and ecological significance, it is sometimes cultivated in botanical gardens for its ornamental value.
